author: Iosaf Bennis
description:
I believe their is a significant viral access weak point when the gloves are separate items to the gown.
The Rear Entry Apron/gown should be produced with gloves integral in the design.
Separate gloves could be worn over these integral for interim replacement during  treatment.
The Rear Entry Apron/gown should have easily identifiable and gripped tabs.
The additional separate gloves should have tags/loops of their own, which can
be attached to hooks which are fixed to a disinfecting spray unit.
Spray is triggered by locating gloved hands towards hooks.
Caregiver/medic slips the loops in gloves over hooks,
& pull hands back towards themselves,  gloves are removed without requiring further use of hands - while being sprayed.

_______________________________

1

Medic/Caregiver dresses into rear entry gown/apron from... the rear.

Gown/Apron has integrated gloves - all in one

Optional Additional removable gloves to fit over integrated gloves.

These can be removed & replaced multiple times during single treatment as maybe required.

_________________

2

Assistant seals gown from rear.

Alternatively can be self closed using 'wetsuit-style zipper/fastner with long cord'

Optional Additional removable gloves to fit over integrated gloves.

These can be removed & replaced multiple times during single treatment as maybe required.

_________________________

3

Medic/CareGiver puts on 'wetsuit-style cold-weather hood' (balaclava style)

This protects neck, crown, hair, chin & ears (has sheath which fits under apron at neck area)

__________________________

4

Breathing Mask & Goggles are then fitted over 'balaclava style hood


________________________

5

Breathing Mask & Goggles are removed first. 'Balaclava-style hood'
Protects from head/neck area contamination

_________________________

6

This can be aided by use of rings (eyelets) which can be looped over to hook(s) fixed to desterilization unit and pulled off requiring NO use of hands

______________________

7

Optional Additional removable gloves removed from over integrated gown gloves.

Medic/Caregiver loops glove ringsover hooks fixed to disinfectant unit removing them requiring NO use of hands to pull them off

Pulling gloves on hooks triggers disinfectant spray
- basically like a switch

___________________________

8

Assistant unseals gown from rear.

Alternatively can be self-opened using 'wetsuit-style zipper/fastner with long cord'

___________________________

9

Medic/Caregiver removes rear entry gown/apron using rings attached at integrated glove area and near chest area to loop over hooks fixed
to disinfectant unit removing them requiring NO use of hands to pull them off.

Pulling gown (w/integrated gloves)on hooks triggers disinfectant spray
- basically like a switch

_________________________

10

HAZMAT BARREL REMOVED -  Possibly Using lever/mechanism
- or removed from behind unit - rolled out

This should be moved into area behind wall/partition/unit which is seperated from area where medics/caregivers disinfection area -
Creating another barrier to haphazard infection?
summary: "Taking it off is the most dangerous part, okay, I would say that if we're going to look at any part of the whole process that maybe needs to be rethought it's the taking it off, because you can the little drop on your sleeve, if you touch it and then touch your eye that could be enough to get infected"QUOTATION FROM Robert Garry, Ph.D., a Tulane virologistMy idea is to try to breakdown this process and using readily available low-tech solutions to try and reduce contact points when removing contaminated PPE clothing. My hope is that these modifications can be applied to most expensivehermetically sealed PPE suits, lower cost light PPE suits, even in areas wherepoverty & health system breakdown requires in-family DIY
title: Conceptualization on Removal of PPE  - "Taking it off is the most dangerous part..."
